Whilſt death hath power from that to ſet me free.

div.head: ACT V. SCEN. IV.
div.stage: Phocas, Heraclius, Martian taking himſelf for Heraclius, Pulcheria, her Women, Criſpus, Guards and Attendants.

sp.speaker: CRISPƲS.
sp.l: TO Exuperius, Sir, the debt you owe,
He and his friends have born the buſineſs ſo,
That he the Mutineers hath overcome,
And Pris'ners brings their chiefs to hear your doom.

sp.speaker: PHO:
sp.l: Command that in the Court for me he ſtay,
Where them their due, my thanks to him i'le pay.
Ingrateful wilt thou be, my Son, or no?
The Mutineers o're come, I need not ſhow
Or fear or love, more than I have indeed;
Uſe well the time while I make others bleed:
And thou Pulcheria, if thou wouldſt not ſee
Both their bloods ſhed to end the Tragedie,
Find, or make choice of one of them for mine,
And with the uſual forms your right hands join:
At my return I ſwear this ſhall be done;
Who ſcorns my blood and Throne, is not my Son.

sp.speaker: PƲLC:
sp.p: Threat not, they dead, I gladly death imbrace.

sp.speaker: PHO:
sp.l: I know thou wouldſt, but i'le not grant that grace,
That were a mercie: I muſt puniſh thee,
Which as the higheſt, thou ſhalt marry me.

sp.speaker: PƲLC:
sp.p: Ha! What Plague?

sp.speaker: PHO.
sp.l: If it be great, from me 'tis juſtly due,
But I ſhall make it yet more ſtrange and new,
I'le bath this in their blouds when ſo, take thine,
One way or other compaſs my deſign.
She will not kill her ſelf, whilſt yet they live To himſelf.
They error me, and I'le them terror give.

div.head: ACT V. SCENE V.
div.stage: Heraclius, Martian taking himſelf for Heraclius, Pulcheria.

sp.speaker: PƲLCHERIA.
sp.l: O The ſly Wolf, his fear made him ſeem mild,
The danger paſt, how bloudy and how wild;
Threatning our hearts in pieces he will tear,
If only mine, it were not worth my fear,
But when you both muſt die, whoſe worth is ſuch,
The world ne're knew, nor ſhall again ſo much:
Since we to death muſt all together go,
Which is indeed my Brother let me know,
That aptly I may pay the debt I owe.

sp.speaker: MARTIAN
sp.l: Rather reſolve, your danger drawing near,
(He may come back, and act what you ſo fear)
The marriage with the Son then celebrate;
To ſhun the Father you ſo juſtly hate.

sp.speaker: PƲL.
sp.l: Who is't will ſhow me, if I could conſent,
And ſo aſſure me, inceſt to prevent?

sp.speaker: MART.
sp.l: I ſee too much of fear for us and you:
Yet a faign'd marriage you may yield unto,
Deceive the Tyrant, vertue not deſtroy,
All live, and yet not Hymen's rights enjoy.

sp.speaker: PƲL,
sp.l: So to diſſemble would look poor and low:

sp.speaker: HERAC:
sp.l: A Tyrant to outreach makes it not ſo.
'Twould place in truſt a Brother which he gives,
We having power, he at our mercy lives,
And ſo we may, when ever we think good,
Sue a divorce, and ſeal it with his blood.

sp.speaker: PƲL.
sp.l: Well to preſerve your lives, avoyd my ſhame,
I am content: whoſe wife muſt I ſeem? name;
Which of you is it offers me his hand?
'Tis not a real, ſince no legal band.

sp.speaker: HERAC.
sp.l: You Sir, who did at firſt the motion make;

sp.speaker: MARTIAN
sp.l: You Prince, who for his Son Phocas will take;

sp.speaker: HERAC:
sp.l: You who theſe four years have her lover him:

sp.speaker: MARTIAN
sp.l: You who have greater worth her heart to win:

sp.speaker: PƲL.
sp.l: Ah Princes!
By this ſo brave retreat your worth is ſhown,
But I miſtruſted ſtill; judg'd by my own,
For great hearts, which the Heavens for Empire make,
Even at the ſhadow of a crime muſt ſhake.
Let us leave all to Heaven and nothing do,
But what bright honour fairly guides us to.

sp.speaker: HERACL.
sp.l: Was ever fate more cruel than is mine?
The doubtful truth, which with my blood I ſign;
Leaves me unworthy ſtill of that great Name,
I ſuffer for, in death I loſe my aim,
Saving not him, for whom I chooſe to die.

sp.speaker: MART.
sp.l: That nothing is to my ſtrange deſtiny;
Who in the compaſs of one day appear
Leontius, Martian, and Heraclius here,
A Tribun's, Tyrant's, a juſt Emp'ror's Son,
And die I know not who, e're it be done.

sp.speaker: PƲLC.
sp.l: How ſmall your griefs are yet compar'd to mine?
Though I confeſs you juſtly may repine;
For death which may eaſe you I muſt not try,
They that give life, that help to me deny;
We are born Servants, and our Lord's deſign,
We muſt not queſtion, but our wills reſign.
It is determin'd by great Nature's Laws,
That all effects depend upon their cauſe.

div.head: ACT V. SCEN. VI.
div.stage: Heraclius, Martian taking himſelf for Heraclius, Pulcheria, Amintas.

sp.speaker: HERAC.
sp.p: WHat does this Traytor's coming mean? ſpeak ſlave.

sp.speaker: AMIN:
sp.l: I am not ſo, ſince I no Maſter have;
The name of Traytor I can leſs endure,
Waſht in the Tyrants blood, I now am pure.

sp.speaker: HERAC.
sp.p: Ha! What ſaies he?

sp.speaker: AMIN.
sp.l: That I am free from ſtain:
By Exupere and me Phocas is ſlain.

sp.speaker: MARTIAN
sp.p: He that betray'd me?

sp.speaker: AMIN.
sp.l: You miſtaken were,
We Traytors ſeem'd to find our Emperor.

sp.speaker: PƲL.
sp.p: Were not both ſent the Mutineers to quell?

sp.speaker: AMIN.
sp.l: Yes but each others minds we knew ſo well,
That when time fitted we did ſoon agree,
To puniſh Phocas for his Tyranny.
For he ſecur'd by our deceit from fear,
Quickly his wonted fierceneſs did appear;
For pride and crueltie do greater grow,
When one believes he has ſubdu'd a foe:
The ſeeming Pris'ners kneeling on the ground,
Implor'd his mercie, but this threatning found;

l.hi: You are all Traytors to whom death as due,

sp.l: Tis juſt, cries Exupere, moſt juſt to you.
He ſtrikes, we ſecond him; the Tyrant dies:
Long live HERACLIƲS, Exuperius cries.
The ſtanders by ſtruck with amazement were,
To ſee one ſtroke deſtroy their hope and fear:
Thus for ſelf-ends who call'd this Tyrant good,
Soon read his ills once written in his blood.

div.head: The laſt Scene.
div.stage: Heraclius, Martian taking himſelf for Heraclius, Pulcheria, her Women, Leontina, Eudoxia, Exuperius, Amintas, Guards and Attendants.

sp.speaker: HERACLIƲS.
sp.l: SAy Madam, is it true? is there a change?
Amintas tells us news, though good, yet ſtrange.

sp.speaker: LEON:
sp.l: Sir the ſucceſs, though great, you may believe,
Nor is there any blood, ſhed, we ſhould grieve.

sp.speaker: HERAC.
sp.l: Falſe to be generous, I thee embrace,
If I have power expect the higheſt grace.

sp.speaker: EXƲP.
sp.l: I muſt beg pardon from one of you two,
If I have injur'd him, I have ſerv'd you.

sp.speaker: MARTIAN
sp.l: Either of both may eaſily forgive
His death, who was reſolv'd we ſhould not live.
Yet at the mention ſomething touches me.

sp.speaker: HERAC.
sp.l: It may the great effects of nature be;
If ſo you have no great cauſe to complain,
If I the Empire, you my ſiſter gain;
Nor can my dear Pulcheria now refuſe,
The Father dead, how can you better chuſe?
Madam, 'tis you alone can end the ſtrife,
Either the Empire's mine, or ſhe's my wife.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.p: And can I then alone the difference end?

sp.speaker: HERAC.
sp.p: Who elſe? on your knowledge all things depend.

sp.speaker: LEON.
sp.l: You may ſuſpect me, yet of artifice,
Believe not me then, but the Emper 〈…〉 .
Madam you know her hand, 'tis you that muſt
To both pretenders ſhew what they muſt truſt;
This at her death ſhe did deliver me.

sp.speaker: PƲL.
sp.l: Which thus I kiſs upon my bended knee,

l.hi: Juſt Powers have me this happineſs procur'd,

sp.l: Before my eies by faithful Leontine,

l.hi: My Son is once more chang'd; the great deſign

sp.l: Not known ſo Phocas, he believes him his,

l.hi: And ſo the Empire mine can hardly miſs;
Thoſe of our friends that yet have faith for us;

sp.l: Muſt Martian love, he's my Heraclius.
You are my Brother then

sp.speaker: HERAC.
sp.l: I wiſht to be
Tis mutual loves yields all felicity.

sp.speaker: LEON:
sp.l: You know enough, and need no inceſt fear,
Nor could that have faln out, ſuch was my care;
But pardon, Sir, that blood I would have ſpilt, To Mart.
As being yours, though none, it looks like guilt.

sp.speaker: MARTIAN.
sp.l: Againſt the common joy i'le not oppoſe,
What Nature makes me feel I will keep cloſe;
Though he from any did not merit love,
A Parent's death ſome inward grief muſt move.

sp.speaker: HERAC.
sp.l: That you your grief the better may decline,
Leontius be again, Martian reſign:
Under that name great glories you have won;
You have no vice to ſuit a Tyrants Son.
You, my Eudoxia, take my heart and throne.
For in exchange I know you give me one.

sp.speaker: EƲD:
sp.l: This your deliverance a joy affords,
Too high, to be expreſs'd, in my low words.

sp.speaker: HERAC:
sp.l: O be not ſad ſince your PƲLCHERIA may To Mart.
Think ſtrange, ſhe yours, to ſee a gloomy day.

sp.speaker: MARTIAN.
sp.l: A mixture of ſuch joies as yet cauſe grief,
Only from time and her ſhould find relief.

sp.speaker: HERAC.
sp.l: You my Preſervers made my troubles bleſt,
Your love and courage bravely did conteſt;
The Victory I reap, your Harveſt too;
Honours are ſtill mine, whilſt confer'd on you:
But firſt to the juſt Powers our thanks we'l pay,
That none but Traitors blood ſprinkled our way.

div.head: EPILOGUE ſpoken by LEONTINA
div.l: MY part was bold, and high, throughout the Play,
In all of conſequence I bore the ſway;
I with my tongue the Tyrant often ſhook,
Now I do ſo, fearing your angry look:
Paſs by our faults in acting, his low ſtile,
And ſeal our pardons, though but with a ſmile.

div.head: Books lately printed for John Starkey at the Miter nere Temple-Bar in Fleet-ſtreet.

list.item: ANdronicus Comnenius a Tragedy written by John Wilſon Author of the Cheats. 4.
Aminta the famous Italian Paſtoral, written by Torquato Taſſo, and engliſhed by J: D.
The Shepheards Paradiſe, a Paſtoral Comedy, written by the honourable Walter Mountague Eſq
The Works of the famous Francis Rabelais, Dr. in Phyſick, a Book highly eſteemed in France for it's excellent drollery, tranſlated into Engliſh by Sir Tho. Ʋrchard Knight.

The Hiſtory of Gavelkind, with the Etymology thereof, containing alſo an aſſertion that our Engliſh Laws are for the moſt part thoſe that were uſed by the ancient Britains, notwithſtanding the ſeveral Conqueſts. To which is added a ſhort Hiſtory of William Conqueror in Latine, written in the time of Henry the firſt.
The Abridgment of all the Publick Acts of Parliament in force and uſe from the 4th of Jan. 164 1/2. to the 16th of March 166 1/4. by William Hughs Eſquire.

list.head: In the Preſs.
list.item: Philoſophicall Conferences of the Virtuoſi of France, upon the moſt curious queſtions concerning man, Philoſophy, the liberall Arts and Sciences, and all other natural knowledge, tranſlated into Engliſh by G. H. folio.
